questions: Q. 2. Name the organ of respiration in an aquatic molluscs and an insect.
answers: Ans. Aquatic molluscs: Gills. Insects : Trachea.

questions: Q. 3. What is glottis and epiglottis ?
answers: Ans. Glottis is the opening of pharynx into larynx while epiglottis is a leaf-like cartilage that covers the wind-pipe or trachea.

questions: Q. 4. Which respiration can occur both in water and air ?
answers: Ans. Cutaneous respiration.

questions: Q. 5. Name the types of respiration based on the absence or presence of oxygen.
answers: Ans. Based on the absence or presence of oxygen, respiration is of two types-anaerobic and aerobic respiration.

questions: Q. 6. What constitutes the conducting part of the respiratory system ?
answers: Ans. The part of the respiratory system starting with the external nostrils upto the terminal bronchioles constitutes the conducting part.

questions: Q. 7. Define breathing ?
answers: Ans. The process of exchange of O 2 from the atmosphere with CO 2 produced by the cells is called breathing.

questions: Q. 8. Name the double walled sac, which cover the lungs in mammals.
answers: Ans. Pleura.

questions: Q. 9. Where does exchange of gases occurs?
answers: Ans. Exchange of gases occurs in lung alveoli and tissue cells.

questions: Q. 10. What is Adam's apple ?
answers: Ans. The size of larynx in man grows larger and becomes prominent and therefore, it is called as Adam's apple.

questions: Q. 11. How does diaphragm help in respiration ?
answers: Ans. Diaphragm increases the volume of thoracic cavity during inspiration and decreases the volume of thorax during expiration.

questions: Q. 12. What is pulmonary respiration ?
answers: Ans. Respiration by lungs is termed as pulmonary respiration.

questions: Q. 13. Name the structure which prevent the collapsing of trachea.
answers: Ans. Cartilaginous rings are the structure which prevent the collapsing of trachea.

questions: Q. 14. How is the thoracic cavity (chamber) enclosed ?
answers: Ans. Expiring all the air a person is capable of through lungs is called forceful expiration. For example, sneezing is the sudden forceful expiration.

questions: Q. 15. What is Tidal Volume ?  KVS Silchar 2017
answers: Ans. It is the volume of air inspired or expired in each normal breathe. This is about 500 ml in an adult person.

questions: Q. 16. What is respiratory quotient ?  KVS 2015
answers: Ans. Respiratory quotient is the ratio of the volume of carbon dioxide produced to the volume of oxygen consumed in respiration over a period of time. RQ =  Volume of CO2 evolved Volume of O2 absored

questions: Q. 17. Name three forms in which CO 2 is transported by the blood.
answers: Ans. As bicarbonates, carbonic acid and carbamino haemoglobin.

questions: Q. 18. Give the vital capacity of lungs of a normal adult person.
answers: Ans. 3.5 to 4.5 litres.

questions: Q. 19. Where does exchange of gases occurs ?
answers: Ans. Exchange of gases occurs in lung alveoli and tissue cells.

questions: Q. 20. What is oxygen haemoglobin dissociation curve ?
answers: Ans. The relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen and percentage saturation of haemoglobin with oxygen is graphically illustrated by a curve called oxygen haemoglobin dissociation curve.

questions: Q. 21. What is carbamino-haemoglobin ?
answers: Ans. carbamino-haemoglobin is the complex formed when carbon dioxide combines with the globin part of haemoglobin.

questions: Q. 22. Which is the common energy carrier in cells?
answers: Ans. ATP is the common energy carrier in cells.

questions: Q. 23. How is the movement of air into and out of the lungs facilitated ?.
answers: Ans. The movement is facilitated by the creation of pressure gradient between the lungs and the atmosphere.

questions: Q. 24. What is the percentage of O2 in the inspired an expired air ?
answers: Ans. Inspired air = 21 percent O 2 and expired air = 16 percent O 2.

questions: Q. 25. What is the role of carbonic anhydrase in RBCs?
answers: Ans. About 70% of CO 2 reacts with water to form carbonic acid in RBCs in the presence of enzyme carbonic anhydrase.

questions: Q. 26. State the PO 2 and PCO 2 in the blood after tissue respiration?
answers: Ans. After tissue respiration, PO 2 and PCO 2 in deoxygenated blood are 40 mm Hg and 45mm Hg respectively.

questions: Q. 27. What is vital capacity ?
answers: Ans. The maximum volume of air a person can breathe in after forced expiration. This includes ERV, TV and IRV or the maximum volume of air a person can breathe out after a forced inspiration.
